text: "Hands Across the Sea" sheet music cover "Hands Across the Sea" is an American military march composed by John Philip Sousa in 1899. ==History== The march was written in 1899. When the march premiered the same year at the Academy of Music in Philadelphia, the audience insisted that it be repeated three times.Journal of Band Research, Vols. 38-39, p. 54. The march is "addressed to no particular nation, but to all of America's friends abroad."Paul E. Bierley, The Works of John Philip Sousa (1984), p. 60. In 1901, John Phillip Sousa heard the Virginia Tech Regimental Band "The Highty Tighties" playing "The Thunderer" at the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York. Sousa was so impressed that he dedicated a performance of his latest march, "Hands Across the Sea", to the band.http://www.greatamericanthings.net/music/music-john- philip-sousa/ Sousa prefaced the sheet music's score with a quotation from the English diplomat John Hookham Frere: "A sudden thought strikes me; let us swear eternal friendship."All Music Guide to Classical Music: The Definitive Guide to Classical Music (Blackbeat, 2005: eds. Chris Woodstra, Gerald Brennan & Allen Schrott), p. 1,295.Music: A Monthly Magazine, Vol. 16. The march was composed in the wake of the Spanish–American War and is idealistic, in addition to patriotic, in nature. "Hands Across the Sea" remains as one of Sousa's more popular marches, and is still performed widely by bands. ==Composition== One reviewer describes the march this way: "Hands Across the Sea opens with a jaunty, carefree theme, the wind sonorities light and generally in their middle and upper ranges. An equally attractive march appears midway through, its manner initially mellow and nonchalant. It gradually turns more animated and colorful, the piccolo dancing merrily above suave wind sonorities. The work closes with this spirited theme playing proudly, the brass flamboyant, the cymbals crashing, and the whole brimming with festivity and vivid color. For band music enthusiasts and Sousa mavens, this three-minute gem will have great appeal." ==References== == External links == *Hands Across The Sea (audio file) - In MIDI format; from the John Philip Sousa website maintained by David Lovrien, hosted by the Dallas Wind Symphony Category:American military marches Category:Sousa marches Category:1899 compositions
